content.description: Start sitting outside the gap, make a hard first move with very unique foot beta, then traverse across the top of the boulder topping out to the far right.
content.location: Left side of the gap between the boulders.

content.description: The face on the front of the boulder can be traversed left to right or right to left.  The right start starts standing on the right end.  The left start starts sitting on the left end.  Both are about the same grade, better quality left to right.
content.location: First face as you walk down to the lower boulders.  #3 on the beta topo

content.description: Start sitting just inside the gap with the two-finger triangle pocket for left and a low crimp for the right. The sloping foot ledge to the right is on and very much key to the problem. Move up and right following the obvious line of the crack.

Start sitting on the left side of the boulder with hands high on a good edge, same start as Outside in, get a high left foot in the crack and make the right hand move up to a good edge on the arete of the boulder. From here rose, or find another beta, to a two-finger pocket (that is the left hand start to Inside Out) and then unwind to a very thin crimp in the crack and bump out to the good juggy hold in the crack that makes up the start of Crack Traverse. Finish up that problem traversing up the crack and topping out in the middle of the face.
content.protection: 1-2 pads, it is difficult to pad in the alley between the boulder and sheared rock behind it.
content.location: Starting on the left side of the lower boulder, as for Outside In, and working right into the face with the sheared rock behind you.

content.description: Lowest boulder has several easy problems.

Start at left end of obvious crack line in the gap between the two boulders.  Climb up and right.  Harder from a sit start (down and left).  Also fun to move up to lip of the boulder and traverse right to the same topout.
content.location: In gap of the two boulders.  #2 on the beta topo

content.description: Boulders slightly downhill from the Pedestal
